WWF Living Planet Report 2016

title: Mini-Lesson: Ecosystem Services
text:
Takeaways

Ecosystem services (“ES”) are the benefits that people derive from nature
There are 4 groups of ES: cultural, provisioning, regulating, and supporting

Next Lesson

Why are they called “services” and what are the pros/cons (2 min intro TikTok)
How are ES distributed across space and time? Who has access and who does not

text:
Futher Resources


6 min podcast on urban nature
TikToks (1, 2, 3) on ecosystem services
Millennium Ecosystem Assessment Report

This is the document that popularized the term ecosystem services

Go outside! Pay attention to the nature around you - how is it benefiting (or not benefiting) you? What about others?

Student Well-Being
Your mental and physical well-being is of the utmost importance. If you are struggling, please feel free to come see me during my office hours or make an appointment via email. Below is a list of resources on campus that may be helpful, I encourage you to use them.
1. Biology’s Undergraduate Advisor: Leonie Morris
2. Counselling and Psychological Services
3. Concordia Library Citation and Style Guides
4. Student Success Centre
5. Health Services
6. Financial Aid and Awards
7. HOJO (Off Campus Housing and Job Bank)
8. Academic Integrity
9. Access Centre for Students with Disabilities
10. CSU Advocacy Centre
11. Dean of Students Office
12. International Students Office
13. Student Hub



Course Description
This course will serve as an introduction to urban ecology and urban studies. We will learn and discuss some of the fundamental theories that underpin how we discuss urban ecology in 2022. We will then discuss the current state of our cities - how they are managed with respect to the natural environment and why. Woven throughout, we will use critical thinking skills to assess how the power structures present in our society influence and inform the ecology of our cities, as well as how we talk about the ecology of our cities. Finally, we will synthesize the theory, examples, and issues that we have learned and attempt to imagine a new ecological feature or management technique in a city of our choice.


Learning Outcomes

Outline 3 fundamental theories underpinning urban ecology
Describe current management techniques of ecology and natural elements in our cities
Evaluate how power structures in our society inform the ecology of our cities
Imagine how the ecology of our cities could/should change and propose an approach



Course Materials
All course materials can be found on the course website (check Locations for the Moodle link). When external media is referenced, such as podcasts and TikToks, the links will be posted on the course website.
NOTE: for many of our in-class discussions, we will be using PollEverywhere and/or Kahoot. These technologies do not require you to make an account, but do require access to a laptop or phone. If you do not have access to these items, please send me an email and we will get you set up with what you need to participate.


Question Forum
There is an anonymous question forum on our course website. This is a space for anyone in the class to ask questions and receive answers from me, your TA, or your peers. If you want something clarified next class, have a question about a deadline, have a critique of how a concept was presented in class, please consider posting it there.



Assessments
NOTE: Deadlines are not currently stated in this framework. We will discuss deadlines together on the first day of class. Please bring the syllabuses from your other courses, so that you know which dates work best for you.

10% - Class Takeaways

Following each class, you will be expected to post your main takeaway and/or question on Moodle (3 absences without discussion are allowed before 0’s are recorded)



20% - Your Favourite Theory Paper

You will select your favourite (or least favourite) theory that is fundamental to urban ecology from class. You will outline the theory, give 2 examples of how it could be used to understand a city, and describe why you think it is important/interesting/not interesting.
There will be a soft deadline for this paper on DATE. If you submit a version on this deadline, you will not be graded but you will receive feedback from the TA that you can incorporate for your final version. If you miss this deadline, you will not receive feedback before your final version.



20% - Management Techniques Debate

You will join one of four groups in the class, each group selecting a current green space management technique that is prevalent in Canadian cities
Each group will craft arguments regarding:

History
Purpose
Efficacy
Equity
Shortcomings

The arguments will be submitted before the debate to be discussed with the instructor and TA.
Following reading week, each group will debate why their management technique is the most important, and should receive the most money in the next municipal budget.



50% - Our Future Cities
Don’t panic! It is not all 50% in one go - we will work up to this.

You will form a group with 3-4 other students. Each group will first choose a case study of a city with an urban ecology (or related) plan that excites them. They will then outline the main aspects of the plan, and why they think it is exciting/relevant (10%)
After selecting a case study, students will outline how they think this plan could be vulnerable to systemic power issues present in Quebecois/Canadian society. This can be done in whatever format the students choose - i.e., podcast discussion, video, written essay, TikTok, tweet thread (20%)
Finally, the group will make a plan of how they would best implement this to improve the urban landscape of Montreal. They will format this plan as a presentation that they would deliver to City of Montreal employees and present it to the class for discussion (30%)

Academic Integrity
We will discuss plagiarism + academic integrity and how to use citations in this class in the first week. Concordia’s definition is here:
Plagiarism:
The most common offense under the Academic Code of Conduct is plagiarism, which the Code defines as "the presentation of the work of another person as one's
own or without proper acknowledgement." This includes material copied word for word from books, journals, Internet sites, professor's course notes, etc. It refers to material that is paraphrased but closely resembles the original source. It also includes for example the work of a fellow student, an answer on a quiz, data for a lab report, a paper or assignment completed by another student. It might be a paper
purchased from any source. Plagiarism does not refer to words alone –it can refer to copying images, graphs, tables and ideas. "Presentation" is not limited to
written work. It includes oral presentations, computer assignment and artistic works. Finally, if you translate the work of another person into any other language and do
not cite the source, this is also plagiarism.
In Simple Words:
Do not copy, paraphrase or translate anything from anywhere without saying where you obtained it! (Source: The Academic Integrity Website:
concordia.ca/students/academic-integrity)
